title: Fix polygon clipping.
body: Pretty happy with this now; I’m confident this solves arbitrary clipping situations.  The code still needs some polish, but it _works_!

title: Revert to "bottom" orientation when invalid orientation is specified.
body:
When invalid value is set, d3 does not notify where is wrong.
It informs me "Uncaught TypeError: Cannot call method 'apply' of undefined".
This is not kind for developers.

title: d3.layout.hierarchy: treat -ve values as zeroes.
body: I modified the test slightly otherwise the negative value is overwritten and the “revalue” test never fails.

title: Reuse sin/cos values during resampling recursion.
Update src/geo/azimuthal.js
body:
Update to keep the functions invert, scale, etc with the returned object.  Else they are not available when returning just "azimuthal.origin([0, 0])". 

I'm using this updated version on cronkitenation.com.

title: Add a couple of d3.geo.projection tests for recent fixes.
Fix longitudes outside [-180°, 180°].
body: This _really_ fixes d3/d3-plugins#24.

title: Fix resampling interpolation along antemeridian.
body: Better fix for #897.  See also: d3/d3-plugins#24.

title: Restore resampling distortion check.
body: Its absence was causing tearing at the antemeridian in d3/d3-plugins#24, although I haven’t had time to investigate in detail.

title: Fix resampling along antemeridian and some more d3.geo.circle cases.
body: Includes tests!

title: Fix another bug in d3.geo.circle.
body: I made a typo in my previous simplification.

title: Fix d3.geo.circle error.
body: Simplified the code a bit more, too.

title: More explicit touch event checking.
body:
### `isTouchEvent` flag variable is added.

As Chrome (18.0.1025308) on Nexus 7 (Android 4.1.2) is returning `0` as touch.identifier, it does not suffice to check by `touchId ? x : y`.

Rather, it should explicitly check if the event is touch or not by `typeof touchId !== 'undefined'`.

I know not many people are using Nexus 7, but I need to fix those for testing purpose :D
It's just weird that Chrome is assigning simple integer, like `0`, `1`, `2` to touch,identifier ...

title: d3.geo.circle: generate GeoJSON Polygon.
body:
As well as clipping against a given circle, you can now generate a GeoJSON object representing the circle.

/cc @RandomEtc

Note: I’d like to clean up the internals for d3.geo.circle a bit more, but that can wait for another pull request.

title: code coverage test
body: Added a "test-cov" makefile target that runs [jscoverage](https://github.com/visionmedia/node-jscoverage) on /src prior to testing. Outputs a coverage.html file with a line-by-line breakdown of code coverage. Currently clocking in at 71% coverage.

title: Add slice-dice, slice, and dice treemap modes.
body: See also: #653.

title: Fix d3.behavior.drag for Android/Chrome multitouch.
body:
It turns out that Android/Chrome's changedTouches can have identifiers of 0.

I suggest backporting to 2.x since d3.behavior.drag is effectively broken on Android/Chrome multitouch.

title: Scale.ticks returns a single value for a degenerate domain.
body:
This diverges from the behavior of python's range() but seems more correct for display purposes.

```
d3.scale.linear().domain([1,1]).ticks(1)
> [1]
```

title: Making scaling of pack layout optional.
body:
In a zoomable pack layout, it may not be desirable to have the
layout scale, especially with padding.  This adds a method to the
pack layout that allows turning scaling off like so:

  var layout = d3.layout.pack()
      .size([100, 100])
      .scale(false);

The value of scale defaults to true so that the current behavior
remains the standard.

---

This came up in the juju-gui project at https://launchpad.net/juju-gui  Using the pack layout, a complex environment with several services was rendering them too close together: http://atl.mjs-svc.com/scaled.png - by intentionally not scaling k, we get: http://atl.mjs-svc.com/unscaled.png

This is, of course, potentially only of use to us, so it's understandable if it doesn't fit within the scope of d3.  If there are any questions, feel free to contact me at matthew.scott@canonical.com

~M

title: Swedish translations
body: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sY_Yf4zz-yo

title: Improve zooming and panning
body: Fix problems when zooming and panning a time series which can also be stretched or compressed: Pinning the graph would not also pin the axes. Modifying the x-scale would lead to strange effects since the data structure was unintentionally shared.

title: Add Query Language for JSON feature.
body:
I want to handle JSON array easily in d3.js.

select, where, group, distinct, count are implemented.
join has not been implemented yet.

USAGE is written in test/ql/ql-test.js.

title: Add tests and fixes for d3.geo.path().centroid.
body: These are from #765.
See the [3.0 release notes](/mbostock/d3/wiki/3.0) for details. For tips on migrating from 2.x, see [Upgrading to 3.0](/mbostock/d3/wiki/Upgrading-to-3.0).

title: Transition reselection.
body:
It is now possible to reselect elements with scheduled transitions and redefine associated tweens; this enables "post-selection" to customize the behavior of reusable components undergoing transitions, such as an axis. This commit also makes it much easier to sequence transitions.

Previously, a transition's tweens were stored privately by the transition and could only be accessed through the transition. This made it impossible to modify transitions created by components: the transition is not accessible externally, and cannot be reselected from the document. Consider the following snippet:

``` js
g.select(".x.axis")
    .call(xAxis)
  .selectAll("text")
    .attr("dy", null);
```

If `g` is a selection, then this code alters the appearance of the axis as expected. However, if `g` is a transition, then transition.selectAll creates a new concurrent transition, and now multiple tweens compete to set the "dy" attribute. Oy!

Under the new design, an element's scheduled tweens are stored semi-privately on the node (in the existing `node.__transition__`). Transition parameters can thus be reselected and modified by transitions that share the same id. If you now reselect a transitioning element, you modify the transition rather creating a competing transition; this should be less surprising and allow greater control.

As a side-effect of this change, it is no longer possible to schedule concurrent transitions on the same element, even with the same id: only one transition may be active on a given element at any time. (Note that you can still schedule multiple future transitions on the same element, and concurrent transitions on different elements.) For example, you could previously schedule overlapping transitions with different easing functions, delays or durations, provided you were careful to avoid conflict. This seems like a relatively obscure use-case compared to modifying a transition, so I believe this is a reasonable change.

This commit also changes transition.transition, such that the returned transition starts at the end of the originating transition, rather than overlapping. This makes it much easier to schedule sequenced transitions without the complexity of transition.each("end") and d3.select(this).

Also, transitions are now simply arrays of nodes, consistent with selections!

title: Better resampling for non-linear distortions.
body:
I've reinstated the original conditional for linear longitudinal interpolation, since the x \* x < ε conditional was not tight enough and hence caused glitches in projections that include the poles e.g. stereographic.

Back to solving the issue that was primarily noticeable in the Albers demo: graticules near the poles would not resample correctly. We made an assumption that a point mid-way along the connecting great arc is going to be approximately mid-way in pixel-space. This is a reasonable assumption in most cases, but there is an area of high instability near the poles, since a small change in distance could result in a large change in longitude, e.g. imagine a great arc going right over a pole, so the longitude will change greatly depending on which side of the pole you're on.

So the new fix is to see if the distance in pixel-space hardly changed at all, and in this case we attempt to interpolate again, mid-way to the new spherical coordinates. I think we can probably improve this even further by borrowing methods from standard root-finding techniques e.g. Newton–Raphson.
